state.response: پروسٹیٹ کینسر میں پی ایس ایم اے کو ہدف بنانے والی تھراپی ایک ریڈیوایکٹیو ٹریسر استعمال کرتی ہے جو پروسٹیٹ مخصوص میمبرین اینٹیجن (پی ایس ایم اے) نامی پروٹین سے منسلک ہوتا ہے، جو پروسٹیٹ کینسر کے خلیوں پر بڑی مقدار میں پایا جاتا ہے۔
claims: PSMA-targeting therapy uses a radioactive tracer in prostate cancer

PSMA-targeting therapy uses a radioactiv: What is PSMA-targeting therapy in prostate cancer? PSMA-targeting therapy radioactive tracer prostate cancer

Prostate-specific membrane antigen (PSMA)-targeted therapy is a type of normal cancer therapy. It uses a radioactive tracer (radiotracer) to target and destroy PSMA, which is a protein on the outside of prostate cancer cells.
What is PSMA-targeting therapy in prostate cancer? PSMA-targeting therapy radioactive tracer prostate cancer

Prostate-specific membrane antigen (PSMA)-targeted therapy is a type of normal cancer therapy. It uses a radioactive tracer (radiotracer) to target and destroy PSMA, which is a protein on the outside of prostate cancer cells. The prostate is a gland that rests below the urinary bladder and in front of the rectum.
The radioactive tracer binds to prostate: Radioactive tracer binding to prostate-specific membrane antigen Prostate-specific membrane antigen protein tracer

How does PSMA PET work? Radioactive tracer drug (68Ga-PSMA-11) is injected and attaches to PSMA proteins (prostate cancer tumors overexpress this protein). The PET scan detects the concentrated PSMA tracer, pinpointing these tumors for more effective treatment.
Radioactive tracer binding to prostate-specific membrane antigen Prostate-specific membrane antigen protein tracer

PSMA PET works by injecting a radioactive tracer which attaches itself to the PSMA proteins on the prostate cells. Because prostate cancer tumors overexpress these proteins on their surface, physicians are able to pinpoint their location with the tracer.

Prostate-specific membrane antigen (PSMA) is a type II transmembrane glycoprotein that is located in the cytosol of normal prostate cells; however, it attaches to the cancer cell membrane in prostate carcinoma, forming a membrane-bound protein.
